entry.title: Re: Can the result of CALL TRANSFORMATION be empty?
entry.content:
1. Lines 6 to 8: is it possible that without error the XML is empty?
    • The XML is always filled after a successful transformation.
    • So, testing if the generated XML is empty or not makes no sense.
  2. Lines 11 and 16: isn't the generated XML always empty if there's an error, why testing if it's empty?
    • The XML can be partially filled after an exception because the transformation transforms field by field directly in the result variable. See the demonstration program (ABAP Unit / Run via Ctrl + Shift + F10).
    • But testing if the XML is empty or not after an exception makes no sense 99% of the time.
  3. Line 12: why considering that the attribute S2 is filled in all cases when the exception CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is raised, and why not using LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) instead?
    • CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is a generic exception with many possible texts as can be seen in SE24 (tab "Texts"), and these texts use S2 or not:
      CX_ROOT An exception occurred
      CX_TRANSFORMATION_ERROR The command CALL TRANSFORMATION triggered an exception
      CX_XSLT_EXCEPTION XSLT Exception
      XSLT_NOT_SUPPORTED XSLT is not (yet) supported on this platform
      CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR XSLT runtime error
      OUTPUT_SETTING_CONFLICT Conflict in output definition '&S2&', attribute '&S1&'
      IMPOSSIBLE_SECONDARY_RESULT Secondary result &AS1&1 cannot be created
      CONVERSION_IMPOSSIBLE Value '&S1&' cannot be converted to type '&S2&'
      UNSUPPORTED_CALL Form of function call for '&S1&' not supported
      BAD_KEY Invalid key '&S1&'
      BAD_URI Invalid document URI '&S1&'
      INVALID_PREFIX No declaration in scope for namespace prefix in '&S1&'
      NO_NODESET Value '&S1&' is not a nodeset
      PARSE_ERROR XML parsing error (&I1&) in '&S1&', line &I2&, column &I3&: &S2&
      UNKNOWN_OBJECT Unbound external object '&S1&'
      OUT_OF_MEMORY Out of memory
      NO_TREEFRAGMENT Value '&S1&' is not a tree fragment
      NO_TRANS_VALUE Not bound to a transformation
      PROGRAM_LOST XSLT program lost
      VAL_STACK_OVERFLOW Value stack overflow
      TRANS_VALUE Bound to a transformation
      SRC_STACK_OVERFLOW Source-context stack overflow
      RES_STACK_OVERFLOW Result-context stack overflow
      BAD_RESULT_CONTEXT No valid result context supplied
      BAD_PROGRAM No valid XSLT program supplied
      BAD_INTERNAL_VALUE Illegal internal value for external call
      BAD_EXTERNAL_VALUE Illegal external value from external call
      ACT_STACK_OVERFLOW Activation stack overflow
      BAD_SOURCE_CONTEXT No valid source context supplied
      INTERNAL_ERROR Internal error
      UNKNOWN_FUNCTION Call of unknown function
      FORMAT_ERROR Invalid XML format
      PROPVALUE_ERROR Invalid property value
      NOT_SUPPORTED Serialization is not supported
      ABAP_CALL_NO_IXML_OBJECT
    • Hence, it's a bad idea to overwrite a standard message.
    • LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) should be used instead.

Demo program for case 2:

 

REPORT zdemo.
CLASS ltcl_ DEFINITION FINAL
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS partially_transform_if_fails FOR TESTING RAISING cx_static_check.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS ltcl_ IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD partially_transform_if_fails.
    DATA message TYPE bapiret2.

    message = VALUE #( number = '001' ).
    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION id
             SOURCE XML `<asx:abap xmlns:asx="http://www.sap.com/abapxml" version="1.0"><asx:values><DATA><ID>AA</ID><NUMBER>AAA</NUMBER></DATA></asx:values></asx:abap>`
             RESULT data = message.
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>fail( 'The transformation was expected to fail'
           && ' because the message number cannot contain alpha AAA' ).
      CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(error).
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_equals( act = message
                                            exp = VALUE bapiret2( id     = 'AA'
                                                                  number = '001' ) ).
    ENDTRY.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Re: The position follow-up process failed because of an e...
entry.content:
Hi @zekeryaunal ,

Please check below information for troubleshooting and analysis of your issue.
In case none of below information can help with your issue, then please document your process end-to-end and share with Product Support Team.

Step-by-step troubleshooting checklist

Follow this sequence to pinpoint the cause quickly.
A. Verify process and template
  • Ensure you used the Global Assignment wizard (not Concurrent Employment).
  • Confirm the correct GA template is assigned and active.
B. Validate Event + Event Reason setup
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Organization, Pay and Job Structures ‚Üí Event Reason:
    • Verify two dedicated Event Reasons exist and are Active:
      • For GA start (used by the wizard to write ‚ÄúAway on GA‚Äù on Home)
      • For GA return (used to write ‚ÄúBack from GA‚Äù on Home)
    • Check Employee Status on these Event Reasons (commonly remains ‚ÄúActive‚Äù for Home assignment while status is ‚ÄúAway on GA‚Äù at the assignment level).
    • Ensure RBP permissions include these Event Reasons for the acting user.
C. Validate Position Management ‚ÄúRight to Return‚Äù
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Position Management Settings ‚Üí Right to Return:
    • Ensure Right to Return is enabled.
    • Map the Event Reasons for Away/Back exactly to those from step B.
    • Confirm behavior for Home position during GA (reserve, allow other occupant, etc.) is consistent with your position capacity and multiple-incumbent settings.
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Position Management Settings ‚Üí General/Sync/Rules:
    • Review any Position Sync rules executed during GA start/end. Temporarily disable custom rules to test.
D. Check business rules and required fields
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Configure Business Rules:
    • Identify onSave/onChange rules for Job Information and Position that trigger on GA events.
    • Look for mandatory-set logic that could reject the Home ‚ÄúAway/Back‚Äù record or the position follow-up (for example, requires cost center or custom field that‚Äôs not set on Home at that time).
    • Temporarily deactivate non-critical rules and re-test to isolate the culprit.
E. Check permissions
  • RBP ‚Üí Role(s) of the acting user:
    • Job Information: Edit permission for the Home employment
    • Position object: View/Edit permission and field-level permission necessary for follow-up
    • Event Reasons used by GA (start/return)
  • If Centralized Services for Job Info is enabled, ensure the user has the right permissions to pass CS validations.
F. Use Admin Alerts and Execution Manager to get detail
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Admin Alerts:
    • Open the Position Follow-Up alert and view details; it often references which record/action failed.
    • After correcting config, use ‚ÄúRetrigger‚Äù as the alert suggests.
  • Admin Center ‚Üí Execution Manager:
    • Check any Global Assignment, Position Sync, or Centralized Services logs for stack messages pointing to missing mapping/permissions.

Quick remediation playbook

  • Most frequent fix:
    • Correctly map the Event Reasons for GA start/return in Position Management ‚Üí Right to Return.
    • Ensure those Event Reasons exist, are active, and have appropriate Employee Status settings.
    • Grant RBP to edit Job Info on the Home employment and to update Position during follow-up.
    • Retrigger the Admin Alert.
  • If still failing:
    • Temporarily disable custom Job Info/Position rules and retry; if success, reintroduce rules and fix the one that blocks the automated record creation.
    • Check multiple-incumbent and position capacity settings; align with your chosen Right-to-Return behavior.

Preventive best practices

  • Keep dedicated Event Reasons for GA Away/Back, and do not reuse them for unrelated processes.
  • Test GA with a minimal ruleset first; then layer custom rules to catch conflicts early.
  • Align Position Management multiple-incumbent/capacity rules with your Right-to-Return setting to avoid occupancy conflicts.
  • Document and permission the ‚Äúautomated‚Äù actor path for GA follow-up (who runs the action and what they can modify).

Hope this information can help you.

Regards.

Thiago Eva

entry.title: Re: using captcha for external learners

entry.title: Re: Odata v4 batch request error
entry.content:
Hi,

Everything looks good except for the location: "ServiceContract & Position," which is repeated in all requests.

Have you tried using the OData V4 receiver adapter with the "Batch Send" option instead of HTTP? I used OData V4 Batch for creation and update operations, and it worked well‚Äîwith the caveat that I couldn't match requests to responses in the response body. There was no information returned for matching, so I had to rely on the order of requests matching the order of responses. Fortunately, the first record in the request corresponded to the first in the response, the second to the second, and so on.

This might be a good workaround for you as well if option with Odata V4 will not work as well for this specific S/4H API.

Best regards,
Mateusz

The translations for the configuration values are already imported into the system. However, when generating the document output, the values are always shown in the same language and do not change based on the user‚Äôs login language.

Could you please advise how this can be configured or achieved in Quote 2.0?

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
Hi @Dan_Wroblewski,
 
Let me bring more details to clarify. Actually, the app variable where we store the account technical IDs has already been created:

Once we retrieve the account technical IDs, we set the above variable‚Äã as follows:

Then, we set the filter condition of the Get Record Collection as follows:‚Äã
 
The formula "as is" works fine but as you can see, we filter the data entity using only the first account technical ID of the array (see appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds[0].accountTechnicalId)‚Äã. The result of this is that only the cases of the data set whose account.id field is the first occurence of the collectedAccountTechnicalIds variable are displayed.
 
In this particular case, we have 3 account technical IDs stored in the app variable:
 
[{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-9077-32de-afdb-816548020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-908d-c81e-afdb-817b0a020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-8ea9-ecee-afdb-817b0a020a00"}]
 
So, our question is: using the above formula, is there a way to filter the data entity using all the values stored in the array?
 
We tried using the following formula too {type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds}]} as you can see below, but it returns the following error message {"code":"unknown","status":-1,"message":"TypeError: e.replace is not a function","rawError":{}}‚Äã
 
Thanks,
 
LM.
‚Äã

entry.title: Can't seem to remove the spacing at the beginning of the report in Crystal Reports
entry.content: I need some assistance in figuring out how to remove the spacing that appears at the top of the report in each grouping. I have created a query in SQL that pulls all the data needed to put in a letter that gets sent out to each tribe in our state. The data is grouped by tribe and lists all the new permits that are for facilities in each tribes jurisdiction. I have suppressed the Report Header, the Page Header, the Report Footer, and the Page Footer. I have disabled all "Keep Together" language in the letter as well. After all this, the report still has a huge amount of space that the beginning of each tribal letter. I even set the top margin to 0.500 and it still give about 1.5 to 2 inches of space at the beginning of each letter. How do i get rid of this spacing? I have attached a screen shot of the spacing I am describing here (Its the area in the red box). Any help would be much appreciated. Thank you in advance! (I am running this on Crystal Reports 2010.)

entry.title: Re: Call derivations on custom event in sap mdg
entry.content: The best approach is to use MDG Address Enrichment framework, it allows you to integrate with any external api to enrich and validate MDG BP address data.  You can take a look into pre-defined enrichment spot and codes as a reference.  Standard framework can be triggered when user input specific address related data and call a popup windows to show recommandations (come from external api),  user can then choose to use recommended one and fill in all fields.

entry.title: Re: how to book Prepaid expenses and amortize over period...
entry.content:
Hello @mallela_pavankumar21 

Thank you for your question

The public cloud provides two standard options to book prepaid expenses and amortize them based on the number of days. The one you may consider as ‚Äúbest‚Äù depends on whether you want full automation with a posting run, or a simpler, controlled recurring posting approach.

The best practice which is also Option 1 is to Manage Accruals with Accrual Engine. This handles prepaid expenses with start date and end date. Then it lets the system post periodic deferral and expense recognition. See Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues and Blog: Processing of Prepayments with SAP S/4HANA Accruals Management

Also, this video tutorial provides some good insights: https://learning.sap.com/videos/managing-accruals-and-deferrals-in-sap-accruals-management-with-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition

For this option you need to ensure your set up is done.

The first step here is to:

  1. Confirm you are using Accruals Management/ Accrual Engine in your tenant. If not, you have to enable it through scope and configuration.
  2. Ensure you have a delivered accrual item type and method for deferrals (prepaid expenses). See KBA 3567857 for more information.

Second step:

Your source document should be for

Debit: prepaid expense account (balance sheet)

Credit: Vendor

Third step:

  • You have to create an accrual or deferral object for your invoice in accrual app (e.g., Manage Accruals)
  • You must maintain a start and end date (within the same period)
  • You must choose a deferral method that supports time-based distribution.

Fourth step:

Here you need to use the standard run app to calculate and post the periodic amounts. You normally do this during your monthly close. This will allow your system to post the expense recognition and reduce the prepaid balance. See Accrual/Deferral of Expenses and Revenues.

Fifth step:

Is for you to validate and report by using journal entry reporting for the periods and reconciling prepaid balance against the remaining service period.

 

The common option 2 is to use recurring journal entries with day-based proration per month. See  Post Recurring Journal Entries and  Manage Recurring Journal Entries for more details.

If you cannot get true day-based proration from your accrual method in public cloud, the clean workaround is to:

  • Book the prepaid invoice once
  • Then post monthly expense recognition using recurring journal entries
  • Prorate each month by the number of service days in that month

Step 1: In your Manage Recurring Journal Entries, create a recurring entry (Debit expense account and Credit prepaid expense account), set the dates you want to run

Step 2 is to make sure you base it on days. Because months have different day counts, you either:

 

Create separate recurring entries per month with the exact amount, or you use one recurring entry and manually adjust the monthly posting (not my preference)

Let me illustrate that:

Let‚Äôs say your prepaid amount is 12,000 for service, the period involved is 15 Jan to 14 April (90 days).

Daily rate = 12,000/90 = 133.33 per day.

Then your monthly postings will be:

Jan: 17 days (15 to 31) x 133.33 =2,266.61

Feb: 28 days x 133.33 = 3,733.24

Mar: --> (same)

Apr: --> (same)


Third step:

Is to schedule automatic posting jobs by using See  Post Recurring Journal Entries to automatically create monthly postings.

 

In summary:

  • You should pick option 1 if you want the system to manage the schedule and calculation based on start and end dates. It also gives you the accrual method that supports your required distribution logic.
  • You can pick option 2 if you need strict day-based proration and your available accrual methods do not prorate by calendar days.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Tales from the go-live - BTP, Clean Core and a Near Perfect Go-Live with Sebastiano Marchesin
entry.content:
SAP BTP expert Sebastiano Marchesini shares his story of a near-perfect SAP S/4HANA go-live.
Working with a famous food and beverage company, his team built a BTP extension to automate invoice processing using AI.

Sebastiano credits the project's success to high customer involvement, where constant collaboration and consistent testing ensured a smooth rollout. He emphasizes the "Clean Core" philosophy‚Äîusing frameworks like CAP (SAP Cloud Application Programming Model) to build future-proof solutions that won't break with system updates.
Learn about the unique go-live atmosphere fueled by snacks, Lego, and freshly baked cakes from the client‚Äôs test kitchen!
And at the end of the episode, Sebastiano shares his words of wisdom.

Sebastiano on LinkedIn 

  • SAP BTP
    Unlock the full potential of your AI, data, and applications with a technology platform built for enterprise, mission-critical business processes. 
  • Learn how students can certify in SAP for free with SAP Learning Hub, student edition. 
  • Visit SAP Learning 

Enjoy listening to this new podcast! 

Apple          Spotify

entry.title: Re: Modify Data in create supplier application in MDG

entry.title: Re: Display configuration values by user login language i...
entry.content:
To display configuration values based on the user's login language in SAP CPQ Quote 2.0, you will need to make use of the language-dependent configuration features within the system. Here's a general approach to achieve this:

  1. Use User Locale/Language Settings:
    The system typically picks up the user‚Äôs login language from the locale settings in their profile. You can leverage this information in your configuration rules to display values specific to that language.

  2. Configure Translations:
    In SAP CPQ, each configurable product or value should have translation tables where you can store different values or descriptions based on languages. You can set up translations for your configuration fields directly in the product configuration setup. This ensures that when a user logs in with a particular language, the appropriate values are displayed.

  3. Conditional Logic:
    You might need to create conditional logic (such as using rules or scripts) that will pull the correct configuration values depending on the user‚Äôs language. This can be set up via the CPQ scripting engine to dynamically load the appropriate data.

  4. Testing:
    Make sure to test this with different user profiles, changing their login language, to ensure that the correct configuration values appear based on their selected language.

  5. Documentation:
    Don‚Äôt forget to check SAP‚Äôs official documentation for Quote 2.0, as they often provide language-specific guidelines or enhancements that can be useful.

If you run into any specific issues with setting this up, it's a good idea to check the CPQ community forums or reach out to SAP support, as there might be nuances depending on your version or specific setup.

entry.title: SAP Start (Mobile): List item selection issue after orientation change
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We have a UI5 application running on SAP Start, designed for mobile usage. The application contains a list (sap.m.List) where users select list item(s) (sap.m.CustomListItem) in multi-select mode (over selecting checkboxes) to continue processing.

We have identified an issue related to mobile device orientation changes. When the user switches from portrait (vertical) to landscape (horizontal), list selection continues to work as expected. However, when switching back to portrait mode, the list items become "unselectable" and no longer respond to selection attempts on the checkbox.

Application UI5 Framework version: 1.120.x 

Launchpad UI5 Framework version: 1.143.x

SAP Start App version: 2.5.0


Appreciate for any comment.

Best,

Merve

entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports 2008 v Crystal Reports 2025
entry.content:
Here are more detail about what's new in SAP Crystal Reports 2025: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-bi-2025-what-s-new-in-crystal-reports/ba-p/14035515 

Here is the link to download a free trial version: https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/crystal-reports.html#try-now

The main difference is that SAP Crystal Reports is 64 bit while your old version was 32 bit. You will need to upgrade the database drivers related to the databases used in your reports from 32 to 64 bit on your machine for your reports to work correctly.

entry.title: Re: SAP Integration Suite - Connecting to S/4HANA Private Cloud OData with OAuth (Client Credentials
entry.content:
Hi @MateuszPiotrowski ,

thank you for posting your valid question. The described scenario does not skip the use of the cloud connector. Instead it makes heavy use of it. The current OData adapters do not permit the integration with a private cloud token service. Exactly this use case is solved with the described approach.

However I‚Äòd be curious to understand your thought process. Are you implying it‚Äòs possible to use security materials that can be ingested here using a call to the IS API‚Äòs?

Happy to discuss your thoughts.

BR

Frederick

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
Hi @Dan_Wroblewski,

Let me bring more details to clarify. Actually, the app variable where we store the account technical IDs has already been created:

Once we retrieve the account technical IDs, we set the above variable as follows:

Then, we set the filter condition of the Get Record Collection as follows:

The formula "as is" works fine but as you can see, we filter the data entity using only the first account technical ID of the array (see appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds[0].accountTechnicalId). The result of this is that only the cases of the data set whose account.id field is the first occurence of the collectedAccountTechnicalIds variable are displayed.
 
In this particular case, we have 3 account technical IDs stored in the app variable:
 
[{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-9077-32de-afdb-816548020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-908d-c81e-afdb-817b0a020a00"},
{"accountTechnicalId":"11f01ec7-8ea9-ecee-afdb-817b0a020a00"}]
 
So, our question is: using the above formula, is there a way to filter the data entity using all the values stored in the array?
 
We tried using the following formula too {type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds}]} as you can see below, but it returns the following error message {"code":"unknown","status":-1,"message":"TypeError: e.replace is not a function","rawError":{}}
Thanks,
 
LM.

entry.title: Re: Report using the "Main Account" field in account header
entry.content:
I found the solution to my problem myself, and I'm here to share it with everyone. üòÖ

If you filter on selection the field "Main Account" in "Advanced" -> "Contains" -> "X", the data source will display the expected behavior. This filter will provide preference for "Main Accounts" (For accounts that have one) and will count accounts that don't have the flag as well. 

Cl√≥vis M√ºller

entry.title: Re: Is the CAP Error Handling approach of "Let It Crash" the right one?
entry.content:
I agree with this to a certain extent, but I think the statement needs some nuance, especially in the context of Node.js applications exposed to external users.

Could you share a concrete example or real-world scenario where not letting the process crash actually led to issues like memory leaks, stuck resources, corrupted state, or unpredictable behavior?

In practice, it‚Äôs not always feasible to simply let the process die. In an HTTP server, for example, a user can repeatedly trigger the same failing request. If the process crashes every time, you can easily end up in a loop like:

  • invalid request

  • process crash

  • restart 

  • same request again

  • crash again

This can lead to:

  • constant service instability

  • higher infrastructure costs

  • overall system degradation, especially behind load balancers

In those cases, isolating the error to the request, responding properly, and keeping the process alive is often the most pragmatic approach.

The original statement makes more sense for cases like:

  • errors during initialization

  • failures affecting shared global state

  • unhandled errors outside controlled async boundaries

  • native module or memory corruption issues

But saying that crashing is always the right approach can be dangerous in systems that handle untrusted or high-volume traffic.

If you have a specific example (e.g., memory leaks caused by unhandled promise rejections, open handles, inconsistent pools), it would be great to discuss where a crash-only strategy truly makes sense versus where error isolation is safer.

entry.title: From AI Ideas to Tangible Business Value
entry.content:
How to turn AI ambition into real traction ‚Äî with the right methodology

Artificial intelligence is firmly embedded in enterprise strategies today.
What many organizations still struggle with, however, is turning AI ambition into operational value.

Too many initiatives stall at proof-of-concept stage, create isolated solutions, or deliver impressive demos without enabling real business decisions. Over time, this erodes trust ‚Äî in technology, in delivery models, and sometimes even in IT leadership.
The key question is therefore no longer ‚ÄúWhat could we do with AI?‚Äù
It is:

How do we move from a real business problem to a confident go / no-go decision ‚Äî quickly, responsibly, and with the organization on board?

Why this matters now

AI is no longer an innovation topic. It is a leadership and transformation topic.

Today, AI initiatives compete with limited organizational change capacity, ongoing cloud transformations, rising expectations from business leaders, and increasing pressure to deliver visible results.

The real risk is not moving too slowly.
It is moving fast in the wrong direction ‚Äî creating fragmented solutions, undermining trust, or introducing AI faster than the organization can absorb it.

What companies need now is not more experimentation, but a repeatable way to turn AI ideas into informed decisions, aligned with enterprise standards and grounded in real business needs.

Problem first ‚Äî not technology first

Successful AI use cases do not start with models, tools, or platforms.
They start with concrete business pain points: high manual effort, lack of transparency, time pressure in critical phases, or uncertainty in decision-making.

This is exactly where proven innovation approaches such as the SAP AppHaus come in. The focus is on understanding and framing the problem first, prioritizing what really matters ‚Äî and only then discussing solutions.

This shift sounds simple, but it fundamentally changes outcomes.

Humanize, visualize and validate with Scenes from SAP AppHaus

From idea to decision: rapid prototyping with SAP Mode 2 Garage

The examples below were implemented using the SAP Mode 2 Garage.

A Mode 2 Garage is a highly focused, time-boxed format in which customers work together with SAP to analyze a concrete business problem, define clear goals and success criteria, build a working prototype, and create a solid decision basis for next steps.

Methodologically, the Mode 2 Garage combines AppHaus principles ‚Äî problem focus, user centricity, co-innovation ‚Äî with hands-on implementation together with SAP Services, the customer, and end users.

The outcome is not a concept.
It is clarity.

Two example use cases from practice

Use case 1: AI-supported user guidance in procurement

In large organizations, many procurement needs arise outside the daily routine ‚Äî often from people who do not regularly work with procurement processes. These needs are not necessarily complex, but they are unfamiliar.

Typical situations include one-time service requests, non-catalog purchases, questions around existing framework agreements, or time-critical requests with limited process knowledge.

As a result, procurement teams face high manual effort, inconsistent data quality, and avoidable delays ‚Äî not because functionality is missing, but because guidance is missing at the moment of need.

Implementation approach (high level)

The prototype was built around a chat-based user interface on the SAP Business Technology Platform, serving as a central entry point for users.

A custom chatbot captured requests in natural language. Uploaded quotations and documents were analyzed and grounded with enterprise context using the SAP GenAI Hub. Instead of generating generic answers, AI responses were enriched with structured enterprise knowledge. Relevant SAP backend systems were integrated to retrieve information such as applicable framework agreements, category-specific rules, approval thresholds, and historical purchasing patterns.

Critical decision points remained explicitly human-in-the-loop. AI was positioned as guidance and decision support ‚Äî not automation.

The solution was implemented modularly, extensible, and aligned with standard processes.

Outcome and time-to-value

Even at prototype stage, the solution delivered tangible value: fewer follow-up questions to procurement, improved data quality at the point of request, and higher user acceptance through guided interaction.

Based on clear decision readiness, the solution was further developed and went live in less than one year.
The prototype did not just validate an idea ‚Äî it became the springboard into productive use.

Outlook

Looking ahead, this approach is well suited to be integrated into SAP Joule as a custom-built Joule skill, embedding AI-supported procurement guidance directly into daily workflows while retaining full control over enterprise context, governance, and process logic.

Use case 2: AI-supported GR/IR reconciliation in finance closing

Although the company was already running on SAP S/4HANA, GR/IR reconciliation was still largely handled in the traditional SAP GUI way. Transparency on open cases was limited, analysis effort was high, and closing periods were stressful for finance and procurement alike.

The challenge was not missing functionality, but handling complexity efficiently and consistently.

Step 1: Standard first

The first deliberate step was not AI, but the introduction of the standard GR/IR Monitoring and Reconciliation Fiori app. This alone improved transparency, established a shared working basis, and clarified ownership across teams.

Step 2: Targeted AI extension

Building on the standard, a complementary custom Fiori app was prototyped to address the hard cases: unmatched GR/IR positions, unclear root causes, and high manual clarification effort.

SAP standard remained the system of record. AI was applied selectively where complexity arose. Document AI analyzed invoices and supporting documents, while generative AI summarized context and suggested next best actions. Importantly, AI did not post accounting entries ‚Äî it supported expert decision-making by structuring information and proposing options.

Positioning towards the SAP standard

Comparable capabilities will increasingly become available through embedded AI capabilities and SAP Joule as part of SAP‚Äôs roadmap. In this case, however, Joule was not yet an option due to missing cloud readiness in the current system landscape.

The prototype therefore deliberately served as a bridge to the standard ‚Äî delivering short-term value, enabling organizational learning, and preparing for future adoption of standard SAP capabilities, without creating a long-term parallel solution.

Current status

Around six months after the prototype, the use case is in business testing and validation, with a strong focus on trust, plausibility, and acceptance.

The biggest challenge is not AI ‚Äî it's change

Across both use cases, one insight stood out clearly: the biggest hurdle is not technology, data, or architecture ‚Äî it is change management.

For readers who want to dive deeper into AI concepts such as grounding, document AI, or retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), SAP provides a comprehensive reference with its AI Best Practices on SAP BTP.

In practice, however, success depended less on technology and more on how people adapted. Introducing AI changes how users trust recommendations, interact with systems, make decisions, and let go of familiar routines.

Rapid prototyping played a crucial role by creating a safe learning environment ‚Äî allowing teams to build confidence before scaling.

Key takeaways

  • AI initiatives need a decision goal, not just a technical objective

  • Standard-first approaches build trust and accelerate adoption

  • Prototypes create value when they enable organizational learning

  • Change management must start on day one

  • AI succeeds when people become comfortable using it

Conclusion: methodology beats actionism

AI does not fail because of technology.
It fails when organizations move faster than their people.

Clear methodology, rapid prototyping, and early change management are what turn AI from strategic intent into operational value.

Want to try this approach yourself?
Join our upcoming customer hackathon

For customers who want to explore AI pragmatically and advance concrete use cases, we are organizing  customer hackathons.

The format follows the same core principles as the SAP Mode 2 Garage: real business problems, cross-functional teams, rapid prototyping, and a strong focus on decision readiness rather than demo perfection.

The hackathons will take place in Berlin, Munich, Vienna, and Zurich.

üëâInterested?
Learn more about the hackathons and register here: Hackathon ‚Äì Business meets AI

If you would like to discuss the methodologies, formats, and tools described in this article feel free to reach out directly via email or LinkedIn.

entry.title: Purchase Order Form - language for countries
entry.content:
The purchase order output displays incorrect country names in French and German languages instead of English, despite the supplier and plant configurations being set to English.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Form - language for countries
entry.content:
Hi,

In Purchase Order outputs where the supplier address and the ship-to (delivery) address are located in different countries, SAP applies international postal regulations when determining the language of the country names:

  • The country name of an address may be displayed in a language that ensures correct identification and processing by international postal services.

  • As a result, the country field can appear in a different language than the supplier master language, plant language, or overall PO output language.

This behavior is by design and applies to standard Purchase Order output templates in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per KBA

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002836612

Thanks,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Adding an Additional Procedure to Existing Serial Num...
entry.content:
• Test in a sandbox/quality system: Apply the procedure extension to a profile with stock and simulate goods movements.

  • Check for inconsistencies: Run reports like IQ09 (Display Serial Numbers) or IE03 (Display Equipment) to confirm serials remain intact.

  • If feasible, clear stock: SAP‚Äôs official recommendation is still to remove/repost stock before profile changes, even for extensions.

  • Alternative approach: Create a new serial number profile with ADVR included and assign it only to new materials, leaving existing stock untouched.

entry.title: Re: Are tax categories for US and CR are missing in the s...
entry.content:
To answer your question 1, the DUNS number (Data Universal Numbering System) is a business identifier, not a tax ID. In the standard SAP tax category catalog, there is no delivered tax category for DUNS. SAP generally expects DUNS to be stored in Business Partner master data under Identification Numbers (category ‚ÄúDUNS‚Äù), not in tax categories. So yes, your understanding is correct: there is no standard tax category for DUNS.

To answer your question 2, Costa Rica uses C√©dula Jur√≠dica as the corporate tax identification number. In SAP‚Äôs delivered tax categories, CR3 (Costa Rica: Tax Identification Number) is the standard field for storing this. So yes, you can use CR3 for C√©dula Jur√≠dica without creating a custom code.

entry.title: Re: Costing has done after process order and user unable...
entry.content:
Options to Settle the Process Order

  • Use transaction OB52 and OKP1 to temporarily reopen the prior month. Run KO88 settlement. Close the period again. But it requires authorization and coordination with Finance, since reopening closed periods can affect financial integrity.
  • In KO88, you can change the ‚ÄúPosting Period‚Äù field to the next open month. The system will then post settlement entries into the current open period, even though the order belongs to the previous month. This is often the safer approach in productive systems.

In short, you cannot settle KO88 into a closed month. Either reopen the prior period (OB52/OKP1) or post settlement into the next open period.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4Hana Public Cloud - Custom CDS View - How do I create a view that extends Condition Record
entry.content: Thank you for your response @Chris1973. So to help answer some of your questions: 1: Are you trying to find/define condition amount during a specific timeframe? The idea for the report I am trying to build is to get the current condition prices for each category that department utilizes as of the time the report is generated. (Ideally for automation purposes). 2: Do you need Condition Table Plus Customer Group 1/2 Keys? Yes. These are exactly what I would need for what we are looking to accomplish. 3: Is the effective price and not the master record your goal? In other words, do you really need ‚Äúwhich price applies‚Äù or to ‚Äúshow you the condition record master data‚Äù? I'm not sure I quite understand... so I will try to answer. In our prior system, the department has a spreadsheet that was linked to our ERP. This master sheet pulled the dealer, retail, and all their department specific pricing levels. It used that data alongside other fields such as weight, Zone and other factors to perform calculations that helped them with pricing determinations for greater flexibility. What was requested of me was to help them find a similar solution in SAP S4Hana Public Cloud Edition and after much difficulty, it led me to asking this question. I am still very new to this environment and I believe it could be possible that a view already exists that does what I am asking for. But I haven't found one yet. But as you have alluded to, I would need to be able to expose customer group 1/2, condition table and I could further restrict the results to their department through product number.

entry.title: Re: Are tax categories for US and CR are missing in the s...
entry.content: Thanks

entry.title: Re: S4HANA Public Cloud (INDIA) - ODN for Supplier Reduct...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud, ODN (Official Document Number) configuration is used to generate statutory numbers for supplier/customer invoices, credit memos, and debit notes. In your case, when using Invoice Reduction, the system generates:

  • RE ‚Üí Supplier Invoice (credit memo posting for reduced amount).
  • RK ‚Üí Invoice Reduction Document (supplier debit note posting).

By default, ODN is triggered only for supplier invoices and credit memos (RE). The RK document type is not automatically included unless explicitly configured. Restriction in Public Cloud is you cannot create custom document types freely; you must work with delivered types (RE, RK).

Try with the below approach

Go to SSCUI ‚ÄúDefine Official Document Numbering‚Äù. Verify that Document Type RK is included in the ODN configuration. If not, add RK to the relevant country/number range assignment.

In Public Cloud, you cannot enhance OBY6/OBY2 directly. Instead, use SSCUI for ODN Category Assignment. Map RK document type to the same ODN category used for supplier debit notes.

Use the Output Management configuration (SSCUI ‚ÄúAssign Output Types‚Äù). Ensure that Supplier Debit Note form template is assigned to Document Type RK. Standard form: SupplierDebitNote (Adobe Form). Maintain output determination so that when RK is posted, the debit note is automatically generated.

entry.title: Re: List authorization objects to be maintained for a dev...
entry.content:
Key objects typically required for ABAP development (depending on scope):

  • S_DEVELOP ‚Üí Controls ABAP Workbench access (programs, function groups, DDIC objects).
  • S_TRANSPRT ‚Üí Transport organizer authorization.
  • S_CTS_ADMI ‚Üí Change and Transport System admin.
  • S_USER_AGR / S_USER_TCD ‚Üí Role and transaction maintenance (if allowed).
  • S_DATASET ‚Üí File access (read/write).
  • S_BTCH_JOB ‚Üí Background job maintenance.
  • S_TABU_DIS / S_TABU_NAM ‚Üí Table maintenance (restrict to development tables only).
  • S_PROGRAM ‚Üí Program execution.
  • S_RFC ‚Üí RFC authorization (if developer needs remote calls).

entry.title: Re: MRP material substitution
entry.content:
Below are some of the Standard SAP concepts you can use

Quota Arrangement allows you to split procurement or demand between multiple sources or materials. You can define quota percentages (e.g., 90% for current PN, 10% for new PN in month 1). In subsequent months, adjust the quota percentages (80/20, 70/30, etc.). MRP will then allocate planned orders or purchase requisitions according to these quotas.

If the materials are interchangeable in production, you can use Alternative BOMs or Production Versions with validity dates. This lets you gradually shift consumption from one material to another by controlling which BOM version is valid in which period.

In Sales & Distribution, you can use Material Determination (transaction VB11) to substitute one material for another. You can set up rules so that when the current PN is ordered, the system proposes the new PN in a certain percentage. This is more sales‚Äëside driven rather than MRP‚Äëside.

SAP has a Phase‚ÄëIn/Phase‚ÄëOut concept in material master (MRP 4 view). You can define a successor material and a validity date. However, this is usually a hard switch (old PN stops, new PN starts), not a gradual percentage split. For gradual transitions, quota arrangement is more flexible.

entry.title: Events from SuccessFactors to SAP Event Mesh (EMIS)
entry.content:
Dear Community

Has anyone successfully connected SAP Event Mesh (EMIS) with SuccessFactors using Intelligent Service Center?

I've encountered an issue with URL encoding of the topic/queue component in the REST messaging protocol endpoint URL, which occurs in both Integration Center (Custom Integration) and Event Connector. The proper URL construction for REST endpoints is documented here: https://help.sap.com/docs/event-mesh/event-mesh/use-rest-apis-to-send-and-receive-messages

Here's what I'm experiencing:

  • Event Connector: The URL is decoded prematurely during editing of the endpoint URL field
  • Integration Center: The URL is decoded at runtime, which is visible in the error logs

Both approaches fail with a 404 error (URL not found). This behavior is consistent with what happens when sending a non-URL-encoded queue/topic component via Bruno/Postman‚Äîalso resulting in a 404 error.

This problem is referenced in SAP's knowledge base, but no solution has been provided: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3120396

best regards,

Mateusz

entry.title: SAP Signavio Process Governance ‚Äì December Micro-Deliveries Highlights
entry.content:
We have exciting news as we head into the new year. 

To help you get value faster, we‚Äôre evolving how updates are delivered across SAP Signavio. Starting in 2026, quarterly releases will be complemented by monthly micro-deliveries, giving you earlier access to improvements without waiting for large release cycles. 

At the same time, we will continue to deliver more impactful, suite-wide changes through planned major and minor releases: 

  • Two minor suite releases* are planned for February and August, focusing on incremental improvements across the suite 
  • Two major suite releases* planned for May and October, bringing broader, more transformative enhancements 

*All dates are subject to change. 

The updates you see below are December micro-deliveries‚Äîearly examples of this new approach‚Äîfocused on removing friction for administrators and making governance workflows easier to scale ahead of the larger 2026 release. 

Spend less time managing files after approvals 

If you manually copy or organize documents in SharePoint after reviews or approvals, this update is for you. 

With the December delivery, SAP Signavio Process Governance introduces a new workflow capability that allows you to automatically copy files in Microsoft SharePoint as part of a governance workflow. 

Once an approval or review step is completed, documents are automatically copied to the correct SharePoint location‚Äîeliminating the need for manual follow-up. 

What‚Äôs included 

  • Workflow action: Microsoft SharePoint integration ‚Äì copy file 
  • Configured by admins via External Activities 
  • Executed automatically within governance workflows 

Why this matters for you 

  • Fewer manual steps after approvals 
  • Lower risk of errors or missed document updates 
  • More consistent and compliant document handling 

‚ÄúWorkflow action: Microsoft SharePoint integration copy file‚Äù 

Let governance workflows handle Dictionary housekeeping for you 

Keeping the Dictionary clean and consistent shouldn‚Äôt require manual cleanup after every review. 

In December, SAP Signavio Process Governance extends automation to Dictionary management by enabling multiple Dictionary actions directly within workflows, grouped as one enhancement and configured by administrators. 

This means Dictionary items can now be copied, published, or deleted automatically‚Äîonly when governance rules are met. 

What‚Äôs included 

  • Workflow action: Copy Dictionary item 
  • Workflow action: Publish Dictionary item 
  • Workflow action: Delete Dictionary item 

Why this matters for you 

  • Less manual work in maintaining the Dictionary content 
  • Changes always follow governance and approval rules 
  • More consistency across shared business terminology 

‚ÄúEnhanced Workflow Action: Move Dictionary Items between Categories‚Äù 

 

Summary 

In December, SAP Signavio Process Governance delivers focused micro-enhancements that reduce manual effort and strengthen automation within governance workflows: 

  • Automated SharePoint file handling 
    A new workflow action enables you to automatically copy files in Microsoft SharePoint as part of governance workflows, eliminating the need for manual document handling after reviews or approvals. 
  • Automated Dictionary management within workflows 
    Governance workflows can now automatically copy, publish, and delete Dictionary items, ensuring that Dictionary changes always follow defined review and approval rules. 

Together, these updates enable admins and process owners to spend less time on manual follow-up tasks, improve consistency, and scale governance more efficiently‚Äîsetting the tone for faster and more frequent value delivery going forward. 

How to stay aligned as we move into 2026 

To stay informed and engaged: 

  • Track what‚Äôs coming next in the SAP Signavio Roadmap Explorer 
  • Request and vote on features via SAP Signavio Continuous Influence

entry.title: Re: How to receive to vendors subcontracting stock with s...
entry.content:
Why you get this error is because, Stock Transfer Orders (STO, doc type UD) are designed for plant‚Äëto‚Äëplant transfers within the same company code or across company codes. When you try to combine STO logic with subcontracting logic (special stock indicator O), the system checks customizing table T161W (PO types vs. allowed account assignment/special stock indicators). In standard SAP, vendor assignment + subcontractor flag is not permitted in a two‚Äëstep STO. That‚Äôs why you get MEPO140.

The standard approach is create a subcontracting purchase order for the vendor. Issue components to the vendor (movement type 541). Receive finished goods back (movement type 101 with special stock O). This is the standard way to manage subcontractor stock.

entry.title: Introducing Configuration and Security Analysis ‚Äì Validation application in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
As SAP landscapes grow and become more hybrid, maintaining secure and compliant system configurations is no longer a one-time task‚Äîit‚Äôs an ongoing responsibility. As an IT administrator, you need clear visibility into system configurations, early identification of security risks, and an easy way to validate compliance with SAP security recommendations.

The Configuration & Security Analysis (CSA) application in SAP Cloud ALM is designed to support exactly this. This blog walks you through how CSA works, how data is collected, how to navigate the application, and how to use the new Validation functionality to assess compliance.

What is Configuration & Security Analysis?

Configuration & Security Analysis provides a central place to monitor and validate security-relevant configurations across your SAP landscape, including:

  • SAP cloud-based applications
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) services
  • SAP Application Server ABAP systems

CSA continuously collects configuration data and compares it against SAP Security Recommendations and Security Baseline Templates. This allows administrators to detect configuration gaps early‚Äîbefore they become security incidents.

Where Configuration Data is Stored

All collected configuration and security data is stored in the Configuration & Change Database (CCDB), which runs on SAP HANA. The CSA Data Stores app in SAP Cloud ALM gives you access to this data in a structured and easy-to-analyse way.

How Data is Collected

On-Premise ABAP Systems

For systems such as SAP S/4HANA, CSA uses an HTTP-based Push Receiver approach:

  • Install required add-ons: ST-A/PI and ST-PI
  • Activate the CSA use case using transaction /n/SDF/ALM_SETUP
  • Configuration data is automatically pushed to SAP Cloud ALM on a daily basis

In case of troubleshooting,  CSA-related logs can be analysed using ,Transaction: SLG1, Object: /SDF/CALM, Sub-object: CSA

SAP Cloud Services

Data collection for SAP Cloud ALM tenants is managed through SAP Managed Connectivity. Administrators need to activate data collection in the CSA application.

More information here.

Navigating the CSA Data Stores Application

The CSA Data Stores application offers various perspectives for analysing configuration data:

  • Store Browser: Shows all configuration stores grouped by system or service type. You can drill down into individual configuration items and view snapshot-based change history.
  • Changes: Displays configuration changes over time for the selected scope, including a complete change history since data collection began.
  • Search: Allows you to search across configuration keys and values for all connected systems and services.
  • Administration: Provides an overview of data quality and availability, helping you quickly identify systems with missing or incomplete data.
  • Validation (New): Evaluates collected configuration data against predefined security checks to give you a clear compliance status.

Introducing the Validation Application

Previously, CSA focused mainly on collecting and monitoring configuration data. With the Validation application (introduced in early October), you can now perform automated compliance checks.

Key features:

  • SAP-delivered, pre-shipped security checks
  • Checks are active by default
  • Checks apply at the service or system type level, not individual systems

The list of supported checks depends on the service or system type.

Validation Overview: Your Compliance Dashboard

This page displays compliance status for all configured systems and services, providing a compliance score based on active checks.

Important notes:

  • Only the latest evaluation results are displayed
  • Results appear only if:
    • Data collection was successful
    • Relevant checks are active
    • You are authorised via the Active Content List (ACL)

Selecting a system takes you directly to the detailed Check Results page.

CSA Navigation Concept

CSA follows a simple, three-level navigation model:

  1. Landscape Level ‚Äì Overall compliance status
  2. Service/System Level ‚Äì Validation results per system
  3. Check Level ‚Äì Detailed analysis of individual security checks

This structure makes it easy to move from high-level insights to technical details.

Configuring and Activating Checks

Administrators can manage which checks contribute to the compliance score by navigating to the Configuration page and activating or deactivating required checks.

Note: Pre-shipped checks cannot be modified. Only their activation status and scope can be managed.

If no scope is assigned, the check is applied to all systems of the selected type.

Data Collection Scope Options

Data collection can be enabled at:

  • Service level
  • Technical system level
  • Logical system level

If enabled at the technical system level, at least one client must be selected. However, CSA always displays data at the technical system level.

Enhanced Checks Overview and Card View

The Checks Overview page lists all available checks per service or system type.

Additionally, the Data Stores card view now shows:

  • Compliance distribution
  • Compliance percentage
  • Overall status based on the worst compliance result

This allows you to quickly identify critical systems directly from the overview.

Conclusion

The Configuration & Security Analysis application in SAP Cloud ALM offers a centralised, structured, and practical way to monitor and validate security configurations across SAP landscapes. With the introduction of the Validation application, administrators can now assess compliance using SAP-recommended checks and take informed actions to improve system security.

Now Over to You

How are you using Configuration & Security Analysis in SAP Cloud ALM today?
Share your experience or questions in the comments‚Äîwe‚Äôd love to hear from you.

Also check, 

For an IT administrator perspective ,

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/exploring-configuration-and-security-analysis-in-sap-cloud-alm-it-admin/ba-p/14295218
